en: Interview with Tim Dale, a photojournalist for WBIR in Knoxville. Dale talks about being in Gatlinburg on the day of the fire to initially cover the smoke and then being reassigned to the fire itself. He discusses that night in Gatlinburg filming the fire and covering the following day at Rocky Top Sports World. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Seeing a tree fall on a car in front of you was a little disconcerting, I guess is the word I would use, but I was never frightened the whole time."

Interview with Tim Dale, a photojournalist for WBIR in Knoxville. Dale talks about being in Gatlinburg on the day of the fire to initially cover the smoke and then being reassigned to the fire itself. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Seeing a tree fall on a car in front of you was a little disconcerting, I guess is the word I would use, but I was never frightened the whole time."

Interview with Tim Dale, 2020-02-21 -- Gatlinburg Fire Department Station 1 Headquarters
Interview with Tim Dale, 2020-02-21 -- The Spur
Interview with Tim Dale, 2020-02-21 -- Gatlinburg City Hall
Interview with Tim Dale, 2020-02-21 -- Rocky Top Sports World
Interview with Tim Dale, 2020-02-21 -- LeConte Wellness Center
Tell us what you do for a living?
Were you one of the first journalists at the fire?
Was that before the city knew how bad things were?
What were your thoughts when you saw all the smoke?
Did you get a feeling that things were starting to get serious?
So they used sand to show the topography fo fire simulations?
As you hear the wind and the trees falling, what were you thinking?
As you came back through Gatlinburg, what was that like?
When you were shooting, what were you getting, the smoke, traffic, people?
Had you met with Leslie yet?
Were you starting to get anxious?
Did your cellphones go out because of the towers going down?
How did it feel when you lost total contact with the station?
Talk about what a "look live" is.
Were you and Leslie together at this point? Did you feel more comfortable being together?
So the station didn't know that you had lost service?
Could you see the homes burning?
Had all the hommes been evacuatied?
What were you thinking and feeling as you were seeing all these places burn?
How does it feel to cover a story in your own backyard?
What kind of impact did this story have on you?
